title: It Is Journalism’s Sacred Duty To Endanger The Lives Of As Many Trans People As Possible

last_post.content:
Love to see how mad the Onion is here. More folks should be this mad about this.

If you want a really solid critique, it's actually here too. They put their *all* into this piece and while it's sarcastic as usual, it really does cover *so many* aspects of how horrible the current trend of "news" in this space has been.

Go read it:
https://www.theonion.com/it-is-journalism-s-sacred-duty-to-endanger-the-lives-of-1850126997

title: The return to the office could be the real reason for the slump in productivity. Here’s the data to prove it

last_post.content:
An October 2022 survey by Slack found that many knowledge workers who are required to go back to the office are spending up to four hours on video calls. Slack’s head in the U.K. Stuart Templeton said that employers risked turning their offices into “productivity killers,” since “making a two-hour commute to sit on video calls is a terrible use of the office.”

That’s the kind of thing that leads directly to quiet quitting.

https://fortune.com/2023/02/16/return-office-real-reason-slump-productivity-data-careers-gleb-tsipursky/

title: Why does the South have such ugly credit scores?

last_post.content:
Wow. WaPo digs into why the South has the lowest credit scores in the country (adding to individual consumers' borrowing costs, freezing then out of credit at all). The answer: Medical debt. Because the South didn't expand Medicaid.
https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2023/02/17/bad-southern-credit-scores/

title: arstechnica.com/information-te...

last_post.content:
Computers have been beating the best human Go players since 2016. The Go world champion retired in part because AI is “an entity that cannot be defeated.”

But a human just trounced one of the world’s best Go AIs 14 games to 1: https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2023/02/man-beats-machine-at-go-in-human-victory-over-ai

I think this news story is more interesting than it might first appear (without knowing details, so grain of salt). It isn’t just a gaming curiosity; it points to a fundamental flaw with “deep learning” approaches in general.
1/

title: buttondown.email/clivethompson...

last_post.content:
Behold "Glaze", a software tool that subtly alters the pixels in a piece of art online 🎨 ...

... in a way that isn't detectable by the human eye 👀 ...

... but renders the image useless for training a visual AI. The AI can't detect the artists' style, and thus can't mimic it and copy it. 🤖 ✖️

It's item #1 in my weekly "Linkfest" newsletter here 📫 : https://buttondown.email/clivethompson/archive/linkfest-6-gps-on-the-moon-8-bit-jane-austen-and/

(Subscribe here! https://buttondown.email/clivethompson)

title: til.simonwillison.net/macos/si...

last_post.content: TIL that macOS ships with a default CLI command called "sips", for "scriptable image processing system" - and it can convert webp images to PNG, but it can also generate entirely new images from scratch using an almost entirely undocumented canvas-based JavaScript API! https://til.simonwillison.net/macos/sips

title: bleepingcomputer.com/news/secu...

last_post.content:
GoDaddy says it suffered a breach where unknown attackers have stolen source code and installed malware on its servers after breaching its cPanel shared hosting environment in a multi-year attack.

The company says that previous breaches disclosed in November 2021 and March 2020 are also linked to this multi-year campaign.

GoDaddy also found evidence linking the threat actors to a broader campaign targeting other hosting companies worldwide over the years.

https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/godaddy-hackers-stole-source-code-installed-malware-in-multi-year-breach/

title: Ron DeSantis is weaponizing partisan media — and weakening independent sources of news

last_post.content:
I keep wondering at what point Big Journalism will awaken to the threat(s) posed by DeSantis, who is a Trump-like power-monger but with more brains.

As Nieman Lab reports, his anti-journalism agenda is deeper and more dangerous, too.

But you can count on the NY Times et al to focus on everything but the danger he poses to democracy. Business as usual political "coverage" prevail for the most part.

So much as stake, and so little media awareness...

https://www.niemanlab.org/2023/02/ron-desantis-is-weaponizing-partisan-media-and-weakening-independent-sources-of-news/

title: https://go.nasa.gov/3Ef1sbX

last_post.content:
"If she says they're good, then I am ready to go."

Before his 1962 orbital flight, John Glenn was wary of trusting his life to a machine's trajectory calculations and asked that Katherine Johnson check them. #BHM

More on mathematician Katherine Johnson: https://go.nasa.gov/3Ef1sbX

title: Continual Few-Shot Learning Using HyperTransformers

last_post.content:
ML algorithms need lots of data and are prone to catastrophic forgetting. We present a new method for continual few-shot learning, bringing us closer to the way humans learn: sample efficient, while maintaining long-term retention.
📜https://arxiv.org/abs/2301.04584

🧵 below:

#AI #CV #NewPaper #DeepLearning #MachineLearning #FewShotLearning #ContinualLearning #HyperNetworks #Transformers

title: “Open Source” Seeds Loosen Big Ag’s Grip on Farmers

last_post.content:
A handful of companies own the patents on virtually every seed planted in the US. Now, a new crop of unowned seeds is bringing biodiversity back to farming. #opensource

https://worldsensorium.com/open-source-seeds-loosen-big-ags-grip-on-farmers/

title: Inside the Heart of ChatGPT’s Darkness

last_post.content:
The second to last paragraph in this @garymarcus post makes it clear how the LLM hydra has many heads:

"So, to sum up, we now have the world’s most used chatbot, governed by training data that nobody knows about, obeying an algorithm that is only hinted at, glorified by the media, and yet with ethical guardrails that only sorta kinda work and that are driven more by text similarity than any true moral calculus. And there is little if any government regulation in place…"

https://garymarcus.substack.com/p/inside-the-heart-of-chatgpts-darkness

title: Setting up iOS’s two-factor authentication for Twitter

last_post.content:
If you want to set up a Twitter 2FA code generator in Apple’s password manager, Six Colors has a great guide: https://sixcolors.com/post/2023/02/setting-up-ioss-two-factor-authentication-for-twitter/

If you do this in Safari on macOS, you can right click on the QR code Twitter gives you, and choose “Set Up Verification Code”.

And if you want easy access to codes, add Passwords to your Home Screen or Dock: https://rmondello.com/passwords-shortcut/

title: Anti-Vaxxers Think It's Time For Political and Legal Revenge

last_post.content:
This is worth keeping an eye on. Great piece by Anna Merlan over at Vice about anti-vaxxers trying to enact "revenge" on those of us who (smartly) supported the COVID vaccines.

In their minds, they (falsely) believe that the vaccines are dangerous. A few months back, I saw someone post something about agreeing to some sort of "pandemic amnesty," in which people agreed not to hold people accountable for positions they held early in the pandemic. 1/ https://www.vice.com/en/article/bvm993/anti-vaxxers-think-its-time-for-political-and-legal-revenge

title: Instagram and Facebook to get paid-for verification

last_post.content:
I’m a proponent of (optional) verification, and I think it’s reasonable for platform providers to charge a small fee to offset costs, but Meta’s pricing ($12-15/mo) is an absurd gouge. Verification makes the whole network more trustworthy - treating it as a profit generator is short-sighted self sabotage.

https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-64697560

title: arstechnica.com/information-te...

last_post.content:
As usual on Ars, there are actually some good comments.

This person wisely reminds us that AI has been littered with bold predictions that human-like AI is just around the corner — and every time, we realized that we’d failed to understand what the hard part even was. The Marvin Minsky quote here is eye-popping:
https://arstechnica.com/information-technology/2023/02/man-beats-machine-at-go-in-human-victory-over-ai/?comments=1&post=41644794
5/

title: ChatGPT is not all you need. A State of the Art Review of large Generative AI models

last_post.content:
Somewhat similar effort:

ChatGPT is not all you need. A State of the Art Review of large Generative AI models

Roberto Gozalo-Brizuela, Eduardo C. Garrido-Merchan

This work consists on an attempt to describe in a concise way the main models and sectors that are affected by generative AI and to provide a taxonomy of the main generative models published recently.

https://arxiv.org/abs/2301.04655

title: How ChatGPT Kicked Off an A.I. Arms Race

last_post.content:
Lots of people think ChatGPT has 100 million users - based on numbers put out by SimilarWeb, who estimate analytics using browser extensions

That number is deeply suspicious to me! I trust the number in this article a lot more:

"But two months after its debut, ChatGPT has more than 30 million users and gets roughly five million visits a day, two people with knowledge of the figures said"

https://www.nytimes.com/2023/02/03/technology/chatgpt-openai-artificial-intelligence.html

"two people with knowledge" is journalist speak for "two separate sources agreed"

title: ActivityPods - Personal data spaces powered with ActivityPub

last_post.content:
This is a very interesting idea to combine #SolidProject with #activitypub https://activitypods.org/

It would make a lot of sense to add more ActivityPub-like functionality in the core Solid specs. Right now it is unfortunate you must use a storage provider that speaks both protocols.

title: When science isn't fast enough to cure your child

last_post.content:
From an interview with Amy Dockser Marcus, author of _We the Scientists: How a Daring Team of Parents and Doctors Forged a New Path for Medicine_, Riverhead Books, 2023:

"The book is arguing that if [medical patients] want to [read scientific articles], you can do that. You can access and read scientific papers, and start to learn the literature if you want to."
https://www.salon.com/2023/02/19/when-science-isnt-moving-fast-enough-to-cure-your-child/

PS: The interview doesn't mention #AccessBarriers or #OpenAccess. Don't know about the book.

title: DeSantis wants to move feds outside D.C.

last_post.content:
What @axios fails to point out for key fact checking and context in this article, is that 85% of U.S. federal government employees *already* work outside of the DC area.

And if you look at states outside the DC-MD-DE-VA-WV area, Florida has one of the highest percentages of federal employees: in 2017, ~5% of federal employees were in FL. Another 8% were in CA, and 7% in TX. <8% were in the actual District of Columbia.

https://www.axios.com/2023/02/19/desantis-wants-to-move-feds-outside-dc

title: Using Core ML versions of diffusers models in python on Apple Silicon

last_post.content: Apple recently released Core ML versions of Stable Diffusion models optimised for running on Apple Silicon. Here's how to run them from python (instead of Swift) https://latent.differentialist.info/2023/02/15/diffusers-coreml.html #StableDiffusion #CoreML

title: These startups hope to spray iron particles above the ocean to fight climate change

last_post.content:
ARGH. "Move fast and break things" might be fine when you're mucking about with a widget to send cat videos in your Silicon Valley basement, but it does **not** apply to the whole planet.

This is an entirely different type of problem, especially when it comes to ethics, system complexity and risk. These entrepreneurs need to slow down and LISTEN to the scientists who say it might more more complicated than that, and the society unsure you should be doing it at all.

https://www.technologyreview.com/2023/02/15/1068495/these-startups-hope-to-spray-iron-particles-above-the-ocean-to-fight-climate-change/

title: Pretraining Language Models with Human Preferences

last_post.content:
this seems like a promising direction
---
RT @arankomatsuzaki
Pretraining Language Models with Human Preferences

Pretraining with human feedback results in much better preference satisfaction than standard LM pretraining followed by finetuning with feedback, i.e., learning and then unlearning undesirable behavior.

https://arxiv.org/abs/2302.08582
https://twitter.com/arankomatsuzaki/status/1627482114982830080

title: Raspberry Pi Debug Probe: a plug-and-play debug kit for $12 - Raspberry Pi

last_post.content: It's new product time! Say "Hello!" to the Raspberry Pi Debug Probe. Designed for easy solderless plug-and-play debugging it is compatible with the CMSIS-DAP standard and provides both a UART serial bridge and a standard Arm Serial Wire Debug (SWD) interface with an open source, and easily upgradeable, firmware. #RaspberryPi #DebugProbe #SWD #UART #RP2040 https://www.raspberrypi.com/news/raspberry-pi-debug-probe-a-plug-and-play-debug-kit-for-12/

title: https://www.coralguardian.org/en/

last_post.content:
With all of the horrible things happening in the world, it’s nice to find the wins. Especially in the area of our environment. A group called Coral Guardian is restoring coral reefs, and it’s quite magnificent.

These photos represent 7 years of work on the Indonesia’s Hatamin Island. In this they have increased the fish population by 5x with 53k corals restored.

More wins like this, please.

https://www.coralguardian.org/en/

#Climate #Environment #CoralReef #Restoration #Ocean #Sea #Fish #Ecosystem

title: United States v. Bhagat Singh Thind - Wikipedia

last_post.content:
Today, February 19th, is the 100-year anniversary of US v. Bhagat Singh Thind, which declared that no person of Indian origin could become a naturalized US citizen.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_v._Bhagat_Singh_Thind

This Supreme Court decision was superseded 23 years later by the Luce-Celler Act, 1946, which allowed Indian and Filipino immigrants to become citizens.
